Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Pliocene Geology, Geochronology, and Paleontology of Woranso-Mille, Ethiopia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research involves multidisciplinary field and laboratory work conducted in the Woranso-Mille study area of the Afar Depression in Ethiopia. The Woranso-Mille paleoanthropological project is relatively new and has started gathering significant fossil hominid specimens from a time period poorly known previously (3.6-3.8 million years ago). This funding supports collaborative research to be conducted by paleontologists, geologists, geochronologists, and paleoecologists from six institutions in the United States and abroad.

Scientists from each institution will coordinate their efforts to understand early hominid diversity between 3.0 and 4.0 million years ago, early Australopithecus paleobiology, taxonomy, and phylogenetic relationships, and establish their paleoenvironments. These will be attained by conducting detailed comparative analysis of the Woranso-Mille hominids enhanced by the use of High-resolution x-ray computed tomography, and isotope analysis in order to test whether morphological differences observed for the Woranso-Mille hominids correlate to isotopic variation that are indicative of behavioral and physiological differences. The paleontologists will further conduct faunal collection directed towards increasing the sample size of all fossil taxa at the site to increase biostratigraphic control, refine paleoenvironmental context of the associated hominids, and identify additional fossiliferous localities. Geologists of the project will establish a refined stratigraphic context for the fossils collected from all of the designated vertebrate localities in the northern part of the study area, establish refined stratigraphy and chronometric ages (using 40Ar/39Ar dating and magnetostratigraphy) for the vertebrate localities and associated fossils, and determine stratigraphic correlations across vertebrate localities within the study area and other paleontological sites in the region. The scientific results from this study will answer questions related to mid-Pliocene hominid diversity, generate new data on the paleobiology of early hominids and their paleohabitat, and increase understanding of mid-Pliocene African vertebrate evolution.

Broader impacts of this project focus on creating training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Woranso-Mille Paleoanthropological project, led by two prominent American paleoanthropologists, is a multidisciplinary research project composed of professionals and students in geology and paleontology from the United States, Europe, and Africa. Major objectives of this project were to understand our deep past by collecting new fossil remains of our ancestors and the animals that lived with them and reconstruct the environmental contexts in which they lived. We attempted to identify the major triggers of origination, extinction, and diversification of taxa by looking at the environmental conditions at different times and how they might relate to the present and the future.  This is important in order to better understand the world we live in today and the interactions between our environment and us and how we can deal with climate change. One of the major accomplishments of this project was showing that even though we are the only human species living on the face of the earth today, in the past, two or more species of our close relatives lived at the same time. These findings will allow us to ask further questions regarding human adaptations to habitat differences and environmental change and why one particular lineage was more successful than the others, such that we are the only human species left and what our fate might be in the future.

Research results of the project have been published in internationally prominent journals such as Nature and the Proceedings of the National Academy of the United States of America, most of which were followed by press conferences, invited and public lectures, which are all important to disseminate knowledge. Many other research articles were also published in specialty journals, naming a number of animal species new to science, including one closely related to us. In addition to addressing its scientific objectives and sharing its results with the scientific audience and the public at large through various publications and media outlets, the project was also actively engaged in training both graduate and undergraduate students from the United States and other parts of the world, and staff members of the institutions with whom it collaborated. This has significantly bolstered international collaboration and promotion of education. One of the most important outcomes of this project is that American students were given the opportunities to travel to foreign countries and conduct research - graduate students to conduct primary research for their higher degree thesis projects and undergraduates to gain field and laboratory experience. These opportunities have not only helped them promote their critical thinking and research skills, but also allowed them to understand peoples and cultures that are different from their own. This will no doubt prepare them for their future careers, wherever it might take them. This project will continue its international collaborative research and training students for many years to come in order to help prepare the next generation for a competitive world stage.
